docs.snippet: A DETECTIVE story without a villain! It sounds like a paradox, but at any rate it is refreshing. "The House of Merrilees." by Archibald Marshall. (Herbert B. Turner  Co., Boston.) is the story of a house with mystery. Though set in England in the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A DETECTIVE story without a villain! It sounds like a paradox, but at any rate it is refreshing. "The House of Merrilees." by Archibald Marshall. (Herbert B. Turner Co., Boston.) is the story of a house with mystery. Though set in England in the present prosaic age, the house is as beautiful and the mystery as romantic and blood-curdling as if its frame had been mediaeval Italy or bandit-infested old Sicily.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 80. -- T.P. Phenlan's Ben Crockett, which recently has been racing in steeplechases, started at 5 to 1, with Romanelli up, and won the feature event of the Thanksgiving Day card at Benning to-day-the Washington Cup, two and a quarter miles on the flat. Banker and Ostrich, the equal choice favorites, finished second and third, respectively.

headline.main: BEN CROCKETT WON THE CUP.; Steeplechaser Took Big Washington Stakes on the Flat.

docs.lead_paragraph: The trapshooters of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn have had to contend with all kinds of weather since the introduction of the sport at Bay Ridge, but yesterday the conditions were unlike anything that has ever prevailed at the club's shooting grounds. There was a heavy westerly wind which continued throughout the afternoon making tile clay targets fly in almost inconceivable directions and affecting the steadiness of the shooters at the marks.

headline.main: SHOOTING IN A GALE.; Crescent Marksmen Handicapped by Pranks of Clay Targets.

docs.lead_paragraph: The great celebration in honor of the 250th anniversary of the settlement of the Jews in the United States, which was held in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, resolved itself into a demonstration likely to become historic in the annals of that famous meeting place. docs.lead_paragraph: SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Corporations are being regulated by rough-and-ready law in Summit these days, and so far the action of the aggrieved citizens has been upheld by the courts. The first trouble came when Mayor Wilcox cut down all the poles of the New York and New Jersey Telephone Company because the company attempted to do business in the city without first obtaining a franchise.

docs.lead_paragraph: The interscholastic football championship of the East was won yesterday by the High School of Commerce. The deciding game was played at the American League Park, when the New York Schoolboys defeated, the McKinley Manual Training School eleven of Washington, D.C., by the score of 18 to 0. The High School of Commerce won the right to play the Southerners by defeating Dewitt Clinton, Morris High, and "Poly Prep" Schools and capturing the local championship.

docs.snippet: WHOEVER loves a doughty fight -- in fact, a series of seemingly never to be ended fights, and a hero stubbornly refusing to be worsted no matter how hardly fate entreats him -- let him read this novel of Puritan England. There is not much history ...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHOEVER loves a doughty fight -- in fact, a series of seemingly never to be ended fights, and a hero stubbornly refusing to be worsted no matter how hardly fate entreats him -- let him read this novel of Puritan England. There is not much history to trouble about, (which perhaps is little fault,) but there is good style here, and lively characterization in Miss Dix's now known manner.

docs.lead_paragraph: The agitation against football seems to have partially subsided. Chancellor MacCracken said of the New York University's action: "We propose to await the result of the coming conference, before moving again in the matter." docs.snippet: One Italian section hand was killed and six others hurt -- four so badly that they will probably die -- by being run into by a mail and passenger train in the Bergen tunnel of the Erie Railroad at 12:40 o'clock this morning. The train ran into the...
docs.lead_paragraph: One Italian section hand was killed and six others hurt -- four so badly that they will probably die -- by being run into by a mail and passenger train in the Bergen tunnel of the Erie Railroad at 12:40 o'clock this morning. The train ran into the gang while they were at work about 500 feet inside of the west mouth of the tunnel and went on without stopping.

headline.main: TRAIN HURLS TRACK GANG.; One Killed, Six Hurt in the Erie's Bergen Tunnel.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first "afternoon tea," given yesterday, at Proctor's Fifth Avenue Theatre by the stock company to the patrons of the house, was a brilliant success. The guests, indeed, enjoyed themselves so much that long before they were ready to go the orchestra had to start up "Home, Sweet Home," and the lights had to be put out. Even then it was with the greatest reluctance that they tore themselves away.

headline.main: IT WAS A LOVELY TEA.; So Nice, Indeed, That the Stars' Audience Forgot the Tea Itself.

docs.lead_paragraph: Frank Yamaki, a Japanese photograher, whose marriage last July to Miss Pauline Brown of 27 Spencer Place, Brooklyn, was kept secret until Oct. 1, committed suicide on Thanksgiving Day in the woods near his home at Northport, L.I. It is thought that he took some peculiarly deadly poison. His relatives believe he ended his life in the fear that he would be assassinated by an agent of the Japanese Government.

docs.lead_paragraph: The gold cup emblematic of the National amateur billiard championship was permanently won by J. Ferdinand Poggenburg of the Liederkranz Club and champion of 1904 last night. He defeated Edward W. Gardner of the Acquackanonk Club, Passaic (N.J., the champion of 1902, by the score of 300 points to 153: Poggenburg's winning average was 11 3-27 and his best run 65.

Every year Wall Street is inconvenienced by the necessity of pinching itself to liquidate the crops. docs.snippet: A few days ago a National Committee assembled in Washington to consider altering the date of the inauguration of the President. The assembling of Congress thirteen months after its election seems to present even a stronger case for alteration of c...
docs.lead_paragraph: A few days ago a National Committee assembled in Washington to consider altering the date of the inauguration of the President. The assembling of Congress thirteen months after its election seems to present even a stronger case for alteration of custom honored by nothing save its observance. And there is an especial reason besides those affecting these proposals separately why they should be considered together.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The situation in the Senate on rate legislation is such as to confound those Senators who from the first have been firm against the President's policy and are still holding the same position. Other Senators who they supposed could never be swayed from their opposition have changed front. Senator Elkins is the first to be reckoned with on this account, and will join with the friends of the bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. -- Favorites fared badly at the Crescent City Jockey Club's track to-day, Go-to-Win being the only one to realize expectations. Attraction, the first to suffer defeat, succumbed to interference. Monaco Maid and King Cole, equal favorites in the third, were outrun all the way. St. Valentine was not fit and The Regent, favorite in the last race, was beaten handily by the long shot Edward Hale.

docs.lead_paragraph: The immigration problem will be discussed at the first National conference held in this country, beginning to-day in the Concert Hall of Madison Square Garden. The sessions will continue through to-morrow and Friday. docs.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- State Senator Frank C. Farnum, a leading local politician, was arrested this evening, in connection with an investigation of the murder of John V. Kopf, County Commissioner, during a political feud. Farnum was held on a charge of murder. Several detectives are still active on the case, and it was stated to-night that other arrests of prominent local politicians will be made in the near future.

docs.snippet: It is the conviction of a large number of Wall Street commentators that the stock market's striking resistance to the stringency in money is indicative of an abnormal speculative situation. There are two ways of regarding it. Either the impatient ...
docs.lead_paragraph: It is the conviction of a large number of Wall Street commentators that the stock market's striking resistance to the stringency in money is indicative of an abnormal speculative situation. There are two ways of regarding it. Either the impatient bull interests have irreducible confidence in the ultimate outcome of the market or they are prompted by the counsels of desperation when they continue to bid prices up in the face of acute money market-conditions.

Blodgett, the banker of this place, was burned to death last night in a fire that completely destroyed his home in the centre of the village, and is supposed to have been started by coal from a stove. Several bags of silver and gold were found near his charred body in the ruins. About $8,000 worth of Mexican money of 1730 was found also.

docs.snippet: ST. PETERSBURG, Wednesday, Dec. 6. -- The immediate danger confronting the Government is a concerted attack on the country's credit. The fear that the Government can be forced to suspend gold payments increases daily. This would be the crowning ac...
docs.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Wednesday, Dec. 6. -- The immediate danger confronting the Government is a concerted attack on the country's credit. The fear that the Government can be forced to suspend gold payments increases daily. This would be the crowning achievement of the Revolutionists, who are satisfied that with a financial crash the whole house would come tumbling down.

After the tragedy he coolly walked out of the house, and after going about the street for some time surrendered to a policeman.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- There is a sandy-haired young member of the House named Victor Murdock, who represents the Wichita district of Kansas. Just now he is being congratulated by his friends over a piece of prophetic luck. docs.snippet: Ex-Assemblyman Joseph J. Cahill was convicted of perjury in connection with election frauds last night in the Kings County Court. The jury had considered the case for three hours, and when the members filed into the jury box Cahill was led into co...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ex-Assemblyman Joseph J. Cahill was convicted of perjury in connection with election frauds last night in the Kings County Court. The jury had considered the case for three hours, and when the members filed into the jury box Cahill was led into court, smiling and confident. He ceased smiling abruptly, however, when the foreman of the jury, in answer to the clerk's interrogation, responded "Guilty," without adding any recommendation to mercy.

docs.snippet: Architecture is a difficult art, and it is less popular in England than in other countries. The reason is, I believe, that writers have dealt with architecture either as an affair of dates and technicalities or as a vehicle for moral disquisition....
docs.lead_paragraph: Architecture is a difficult art, and it is less popular in England than in other countries. The reason is, I believe, that writers have dealt with architecture either as an affair of dates and technicalities or as a vehicle for moral disquisition. The first method has little interest for the layman, and the latter none at all for the artist.

headline.main: Architecture.

docs.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Railroad employes launched a movement of protest yesterday against President Roosevelt's policy of railroad rate regulation. Two rival organizations claimed responsibility for the meeting, which was held at the Briggs House. One was the Railroad Employes' Twentieth Century Club which adopted resolutions approving the President's policy a few nights ago, and the other was made up of representatives of the various railway brotherhoods.

Kimbough, was found in his room in a state of coma, the result of having been compelled by upper classmen to repeatedly stand on his head.
docs.abstract: Midshipman Kimbough found in coma in his room as result of hazing

docs.lead_paragraph: It is well understood that any man who incurs the enmity of the structural iron workers on a job is almost sure to "meet with accident" if he foolishly persists in staying on the work. I well remember a talk I once had with an old foreman concerning this subject. He told of twice having seen men drop a wrench or other tool upon the head of an unsuspecting victim two or three stories below.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Red Tape came to the front to-day in a way that shocked even the departmental mossbacks who live by rule, regulation, and precedent. Speaking through the Lighthouse Board, Red Tape summarily removed from the Government's payroll the crew of Relief Lightship No. 58; the stopping of wages to date from the moment of the sinking of the vessel, just after the crew had been forced to abandon the storm-torn craft.

headline.main: LIGHTSHIP CREW OFF PAY.; Red Tape Operates Against Men Taken from Sinking Vessel.

docs.snippet: The Erie Railroad, it was announced yesterday, has determined upon the construction of an electric line from Binghamton, N.Y., to Corning, a distance of seventy-six miles. The new line will parallel the present line of the Erie between these two p...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Erie Railroad, it was announced yesterday, has determined upon the construction of an electric line from Binghamton, N.Y., to Corning, a distance of seventy-six miles. The new line will parallel the present line of the Erie between these two points, and is intended to care for local passenger traffic. The surveys for the line are to be made immediately, and the contracts for the construction work will be let probably in January.

docs.lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Dec. 14. -- Above the headwaters of Stickine River, in British Columbia, not far from the Alaskan boundary, the Interior Indians have found immonsely rich gold quartz ledges on the mountain side, the surface of which was stripped off last Spring by a landslide. The Indians spent the Summer picking out pure gold nuggets and carrying them to their villages in sacks made from hides.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mrs. Annie T. Florence, widow of the comedian, William J. Florence, is ill, and very little hope for her recovery is entertained by her relatives. Mrs. Florence, who married Howard Coveney, the English actor, thirteen years ago, is now 76 years old. docs.lead_paragraph: IT is said that "of all histories, the history of Ireland is the saddest." Many years ago Mr. Goldwin Smith tried to show that Ireland's sorrows were in great part due to natural circumstances and historical accident. It is evident that his point of view has not changed. docs.lead_paragraph: BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- Emperor William's Adjutant, Lieut. Gen. von Plessen, met the Japanese prisoners of war who are passing through Germany from Russia, at 6 o'clock this morning, with large supplies of chocolate and cigarettes, and for the officers bouquets of chrysanthemums. There were 1,728 men and 58 officers, and they were much touched by the Emperor's thoughtfulness in giving them the first opportunity of seeing the flower of their native land.

docs.lead_paragraph: The precipitate manner in which stocks were sold on the opening of the market yesterday morning betrayed the character of the bull account that had been built up in the last few weeks. Enthusiastic followers of the advance had been overtrading, a lot of commission house holdings were weakly margined, stop-loss orders had accumulated dangerously, and a scare was all that was needed to cause a bad break.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The visit of A.J. Cassatt to Washington yesterday has produced a significant move on the part of Senator Penrose, which is being variously commented upon. The Senator had a conference with Mr. Cassatt and Mr. Patton, his ch...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The visit of A.J. Cassatt to Washington yesterday has produced a significant move on the part of Senator Penrose, which is being variously commented upon. The Senator had a conference with Mr. Cassatt and Mr. Patton, his chief assistant, yesterday, and Mr. Cassatt also had a talk with Senator Knox and several other Eastern Senators, who have been regarded as aligned on the side of opposition to rate legislation.

headline.main: CASSATT CONVERTS PENROSE.; Pennsylvania Senator Now Prepared to Support Rate Legislation.

docs.snippet: Two cases suspected by the medical officers on Governors Island to be smallpox developed among the 340 prisoners in Castle Williams, the military prison of the Department of the East, yesterday. The victims, Charles Patten and Henry Frank, were im...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two cases suspected by the medical officers on Governors Island to be smallpox developed among the 340 prisoners in Castle Williams, the military prison of the Department of the East, yesterday. The victims, Charles Patten and Henry Frank, were immediately isolated. They were put in a tent about 1,000 yards away from the soldiers' barracks.

headline.main: A SMALLPOX SCARE AT CASTLE WILLIAMS; Two Prisoners Isolated by the Medical Officers. DIAGNOSIS STILL IN DOUBT Little Prince and Princess Cantacuzene with Their Grandparents, Gen. and Mrs. Grant, on the Island.

docs.lead_paragraph: October broke all previous records of pig iron production with an average make of 66,231.4 gross tons per day. The daily average for November was 67,134 gross tons. docs.lead_paragraph: Three men were killed, a score injured, seven of them seriously, and the lives of many persons put in danger yesterday morning through an explosion of dynamite in the excavation for the new Altman Building, at Thirty-fourth Street, diagonally opposite the Waldorf-Astoria. Buildings in the neighborhood were bombarded with heavy pieces of rock, and smaller pieces fell in the crowded streets after being carried high above the housetops like shrapnel.

docs.lead_paragraph: About fifty students assembled in the theatre of the Fordham University yesterday afternoon, adopted the new constitution and by-laws of the Fordham University Athletic Association, elected officers, and filled the vacant managerships of the various teams. The constitution and by-laws were compiled by three members of the undergraduate body -- Richard Baker, Jr., 1906; Thomas Mansfield, 1906, and William Fallon, 1908, and were submitted to the Alumni Athletic Committee for its consideration.

But wrought iron does not wear as well under the streets of New York, largely owing to electrolysis, and a fund for replacing it has to be created.

docs.lead_paragraph: This morning's news from Russia is anything but reassuring. There is now little doubt that a general strike has been "ordered," no one knows exactly by whom, and that a strenuous effort will be made to carry it out. That will almost inevitably be followed by more disorder and by further efforts at repression.

docs.lead_paragraph: EMPORIA, Kan., Dec. 19. -- There is no doubt here that the ditching of the Santa Fe passenger train at Lang this morning was the work of wreckers. It was discovered this morning that the toolhouse near Emporia. Junction had been broken into and a claw bar and wrench stolen. This afternoon the wrench and claw bar were found in a meadow near the scene of the wreck.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision by Thaddeus S. Sharretts, the Board of United States General Appraisers overruled yesterday a claim made by Leo Popper Sons, New York, it being held that reflectors for lamps are properly dutiable under the Dingley tariff at the rate of 45 per cent., under the provision for manufactures of glass and metal. The importers contended for lower duty, but the board found their claims to be without merit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Although the University Council of Columbia University met yesterday afternoon and took final action on the abolition of football, the fate of the Football Association, which was ordered to disband on Dec. 31, still hangs in the balance, as far as the student body is informed. No announcement was made by the council of its decision, other than a promise of a public statement to-morrow.

docs.lead_paragraph: Peter Latham, the world's champion racquet player and ex-champion at court tennis, and George Standing, American champion at racquets, will meet for the racquet championship of the United States. The match will be played on the courts of the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York on Saturday, Jan. 6. The match is the most important arranged for this country since 1900, when Latham defeated Standing for the American championship.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- It was learned to-night on high Republican authority that Secretary Joseph B. Bishop is not the only Panama Canal official who is threatened with serious trouble. According to this authority, either Mr. Shonts's methods wil...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- It was learned to-night on high Republican authority that Secretary Joseph B. Bishop is not the only Panama Canal official who is threatened with serious trouble. According to this authority, either Mr. Shonts's methods will have to be changed radically or he will be in imminent danger of losing his head. Before the session is much older, it is stated, there will be a general overhauling of the canal administration.

In some quarters efforts wore made to produce the impression that these interests were doing in Sloss-Sheffield what they had previously done in Tennessee Coal and Iron, namely, acquiring control by purchases of stock in the open market.

docs.snippet: Consul General Uchida received a cable dispatch from the Japanese Department of Finance yesterday announcing the Government's intention of beginning the redemption next March of the 100,000,000 yen ($50,000,000) of 6 per cent. bonds issued in Marc...
docs.lead_paragraph: Consul General Uchida received a cable dispatch from the Japanese Department of Finance yesterday announcing the Government's intention of beginning the redemption next March of the 100,000,000 yen ($50,000,000) of 6 per cent. bonds issued in March, 1905. The bonds were in the nature of a temporary advance to the Government, and were taken up almost exclusively by Japanese.

headline.main: JAP 6S TO BE REDEEMED SOON; Loan of $50,000,000 to the Government to be Returned in Three Payments.

docs.lead_paragraph: LAKEWOOD, Dec. 20. -- The grave or Mrs. Carrie Brouwer, the wife of Dr. Frank R. Brouwer of Toms River, whose relatives declare that she was poisoned, was opened late this afternoon and her body was exhumed. An autopsy will be made to-morrow.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new ferry houses of the Lackawanna Railroad and the Central Railroad of New Jersey, at the foot of West Twenty-third Street, perhaps the finest terminals of their kind on the American continent, were practically destroyed by fire yesterday. docs.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 21. -- The strike started here at noon. docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 21. -- In the market today the demand for money was increased by the call nominally for $10,000,000 of the last Japanese 4 1/2 per cent. loan, which, however, had been anticipated by the release of a large amount of Japanese money. Discounts were easier, influenced by the tone of the market generally, and by the probable shipment of $25,000,000 from Russia to Berlin.

docs.snippet: The "United States of Europe" has long been deemed a visionary dream. Politically and racially it is a bogy which need not affright us into building battleships or maintaining armies. But commercially there are signs of the times better worth our ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The "United States of Europe" has long been deemed a visionary dream. Politically and racially it is a bogy which need not affright us into building battleships or maintaining armies. But commercially there are signs of the times better worth our attention than diplomatic or dynastic alliances. They are fleeting combinations, formed upon considerations affecting transatlantic interests remote from our own, which they touch only at points of universal human interest.

At the end of two twenty-minute halves neither side had been able to score a touch-down or get near enough to their opponent's goal to score by a place or drop kick.

headline.main: TEN-YARD RULE A FAILURE.; Only Seven First Downs Made in Test Game in Kansas.

docs.lead_paragraph: A real county fair opened last night in Madison Square Garden, and while there were few genuine farmers in the audience, there were unfaded country citizens attendant on the show to see that their cattle were not starved or allowed to go without water too long. These York State folks pottered around with some querulousness during the entire evening, consoling "bossy" for the discomforts of city life or patting the sleek sides of heifers.

It is alleged that mail for Senator Blackburn, who is a candidate for re-election in one of the bitterest fights that ever was fought out in that State, has been tampered with. The rival candidate is Judge Paynter.

docs.lead_paragraph: Because they were outvoted by a majority of one, the Columbia, Harvard, and Cornell Fencing Clubs yesterday resigned from the Intercollegiate Fencing League. The annual meeting was held in the New York Athletic Club and it was the stormiest meeting in the history of the league. Delegates were present from all the clubs in the organization, including, besides the three retiring ones, West Point, Annapolis, University of Pennsylvania, and Yale.

docs.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURG, Dec. 27. -- A report current here, which lacks official confirmation, is that the Republic Iron and Steel Company, the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, Sloss-Sheffield Iron Company, and La Belle Iron Company have been merged and will be incorporated, probably under the Republic's charter. The combined capital of the four concerns is $150,000,000, and this, it is said, will be increased when the combination is completed.

docs.snippet: Since England has had a poor law its workhouse population has never been so large as now. The number of paupers is larger than in any year of forty except four, and the ratio of paupers to population is the highest since 1874. No wonder the unempl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Since England has had a poor law its workhouse population has never been so large as now. The number of paupers is larger than in any year of forty except four, and the ratio of paupers to population is the highest since 1874. PETERSBURG, Dec. 27. -- A Kharkoff dispatch says that twenty-two members of the Railway Committee at Kharkoff who had formed a Provisional Government were arrested on Dec. 25. The following day a general strike and an armed rising were proclaimed, the revolutionaries intrenching themselves inside the locomotive works, whence they were driven by artillery fire, 100 being killed or wounded.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new complication has arisen in connection with the election of the President of the French Republic, which takes place on the 18th of next month. The election is made by the members of the two branches of the national Legislature, who meet at the appointed time for that purpose alone, possessing on that occasion no legislative powers, or even the privilege of discussion.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Judge William L. Penfield of Indiana, who has been solicitor for the State Department for nearly eight years, has sent in his resignation of that office, to take effect at once. It is his announced intention to resume the private practice of law. It is also announced that the resignation was entirely voluntary, and that it is a matter of regret to Secretary Root and the other State Department officials.

docs.lead_paragraph: A dense fog enveloped the harbor yesterday morning, endangering the shipping. The murky mantle hung especially thick between the Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Jersey shores, and made the trips of the crowded ferryboats hazardous. The municipal ferryboats to Richmond did not attempt to run on time, and slipped through the gloom at slow and measured pace.

docs.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Dec. 29. -- Passengers in the waiting rooms and cafe of Camden Station were startled at 4 o'clock this morning by the roar of an explosion in the mouth of the Baltimore and Ohio Belt Line tunnel. docs.lead_paragraph: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 29. -- Several silk failures are impending, owing to the general depression in the silk trade. Two were recorded here to-day. The Liberty Silk Company, with factories in West Fifty-seventh Street, New York City, and at Horneilsville, have been forced to the wall by an attachment issued to-day on the application of Knipscher Maas, silk dyers.

docs.snippet: Art conceived in America and executed in Europe has come into collision with insufficiently protected American Industry. It appears that certain sculptors having contracts with the Government have had their marble-cutting and bronze-casting done a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Art conceived in America and executed in Europe has come into collision with insufficiently protected American Industry. It appears that certain sculptors having contracts with the Government have had their marble-cutting and bronze-casting done abroad by cheap labor, and the resultant statues, being Government property, have been imported duty free, to the grief and injury of the better paid domestic modelers, marble cutters, and bronze founders.

docs.snippet: ALBANY, Dec. 29.-- State Controller Otto Kelsey, summarizing the work of his department for the year, says the cash balance in the Treasury on Sept. 30 was $10,557,014.97. The bonded debt on that date was $11,155,660, but the canal debt sinking fu...
docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Dec. 29.-- State Controller Otto Kelsey, summarizing the work of his department for the year, says the cash balance in the Treasury on Sept. 30 was $10,557,014.97. The bonded debt on that date was $11,155,660, but the canal debt sinking fund of $4,607,457.97 covers a portion of this debt, leaving the net bonded debt of the State $6,548,202.03, which includes the $2,000,000 first issue for the barge canal.

headline.main: STATE HAS $10,557,014 CASH.; Revenue Exceeds Year's Expenditures by $616,219 -- Departmental Reports.

docs.snippet: LONDON, Dec. 29, 1905. -- The British publishers have come to the end of the book year for 1905, and for the moment they are practically inactive. Taking into account the fact that there will be no good business in books until the general election...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 29, 1905. -- The British publishers have come to the end of the book year for 1905, and for the moment they are practically inactive. Taking into account the fact that there will be no good business in books until the general elections are over, they are in no hurry about making plans for next year's work. With reference to the year just closed, most of them express a fair amount of satisfaction.

headline.main: END OF THE BOOK YEAR IN ENGLAND.; A Resume of the Whole Year's Output -- Fewer Books Published Than in 1904.

docs.lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 30. -- Frank Steunenberg, formerly Governor of Idaho, was killed to-night by a bomb at his home in Caldwell. docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The amount of business transacted on the Stock Exchange this week was extremely small, both the monetary and political conditions discouraging investment and speculation. The ease prevailing in the money market last week lasted but a few days, so that when the Stock Exchange people got back from their Christmas holidays they found a scarcity of credits and higher loan rates.

docs.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 30, 6 P.M. -- Gov. Gen. Doubassoff to-day assumed the offensive against the revolutionary stronghold in the Northwestern, or Presna, quarter, and all day the inhabitants of the city have been listening to the thunder of cannon and the rattle of small arms. At this writing firing is still audible, but more distant, and the lurid glare in the heavens shows that many structures are in flames.
